Wagner Labor ArchiveElmer Holmes Bobst Library70 Washington Square South2nd FloorNew York, NY 10012(212) 998-2596special.collections@nyu.eduThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2021-07-09T19:46:49Finding aid written in EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard Materials are in English.
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Marian Swerdlow Collection on Transport Workers Union of America (TWU), Local 100
Swerdlow, Marian, 1949-
Swerdlow, Marian, 1949-
WAG.367
3.75 linear feet in 7 manuscript boxes and 1 half manuscript box
1978-2008 1980-1986 Marian Swerdlow (1949 - ) is a sociologist, a former New York City subway conductor, and a former member of the Transport Workers of America (TWU), Local 100. Swerdlow was an active supporter of Local 100 opposition campaigns led by Arnold Cherry in the late 1970s and 1980s, and started the newsletter Hell on Wheels to disseminate information and support the slate of opposition candidates that later became the reform caucus New Directions. The Marian Swerdlow Collection on Transport Workers Union of America (TWU), Local 100 (dated 1978-2008) consists of materials collected by Swerdlow documenting her experiences as a subway conductor, as well as the opposition groups and reform movements within TWU Local 100 in the late 20th century. Materials include newsletters, newspaper clippings, notebooks from meetings, and ephemera concerning actions, strikes, contract campaigns, challenges to incumbent union leadership, Local 100 elections, Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA) engagement with transit workers, and the safety and working conditions of transit workers. Opposition newsletters include Hell on Wheels and Rank and File Advocate. The collection also includes sociological papers and conference presentations by Swerdlow on various labor topics based in part on her personal experiences. This collection documents the working conditions of transit workers, coverage of TWU in the media, and the conflict in leadership within Local 100 between the incumbent Willie James and the reform movement of New Directions. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Scope and Contents
The Marian Swerdlow Collection on Transport Workers Union of America (TWU), Local 100 (dated 1978-2008) consists of materials collected by Swerdlow documenting her experiences as a subway conductor, as well as the opposition groups and reform movements within TWU Local 100 in the late 20th century. Materials include newsletters, newspaper clippings, notebooks from meetings, and ephemera concerning actions, strikes, contract campaigns, challenges to incumbent union leadership, Local 100 elections, Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA) engagement with transit workers, and the safety and working conditions of transit workers. Opposition newsletters include Hell on Wheels and Rank and File Advocate. The collection also includes sociological papers and conference presentations by Swerdlow on various labor topics based in part on her personal experiences. This collection documents the working conditions of transit workers, coverage of TWU in the media, and the conflict in leadership within Local 100 between the incumbent Willie James and the reform movement of New Directions.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the roughly chronological order in which they were received from the donor, with the exception of notebooks which are at the end of the collection.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Marian Swerdlow in July 2021; the accession number associated with this gift is 2021.032.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Marian Swerdlow Collection on Transport Workers Union of America (TWU), Local 100; WAG 367; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
At the time of accessioning materials were rehoused in archival boxes, maintaining the donor's original folders and original order. Materials were described on the collection-level with a folder-level inventory.
Biographical Note
Marian Swerdlow (1949 - ) is a sociologist, a former New York City subway conductor, and a former member of the Transport Workers of America (TWU), Local 100. Swerdlow was an active supporter of Local 100 opposition campaigns led by Arnold Cherry in the late 1970s and 1980s, and started the newsletter Hell on Wheels to disseminate information and support the slate of opposition candidates that later became the reform caucus New Directions. She published a memoir of her experiences, Underground Woman: My Four Years as a New York City Subway Conductor in 1998.
